Award.AwardTitle: PFI:AIR-TT: Personal Whole Slide Imaging Device with Liquid Lenses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This PFI: AIR Technology Translation project focuses on reducing the system dimension and process complexity of whole slide imaging in digital pathology. This is important because optical examination of pathological slides is a primary approach for disease diagnosis and peer consultations. Whole slide imaging that can capture the entire slide with high optical resolutions has been proven effective to advance an understanding of genetics, proteomics, genomics, and cellomics, which has greatly improved clinical outcomes. However, the prohibitive cost and limited availability of whole slide imaging (WSI) equipment have set a huge barrier for wide adoption of this technology. This project will address the unmet market need for affordable digital pathology equipment by developing a personal WSI device that allows pathologists to acquire and share pathological slides using their smartphones or tablet computers.

To do this, the project will translate prior research results on an adaptive liquid lenses technology using a composite elastomer-liquid zoom lens with one single actuation unit, which will reduce the system dimension and process complexity of whole slide imaging. It can change the zoom ratio with only one actuation input without compromising the optical resolution and miniaturization nature of the adaptive imaging system. It also eliminates the need for displacing or replacing solid optical elements for changing the optical magnification. The project will result in a prototype of personal whole slide imaging device with a composite elastomer-liquid zoom lens.

This personal whole slide imaging device has the following unique features: the two liquid lenses within the composite zoom lens can be actuated simultaneously and synchronously; only one actuation unit is needed for driving the composite zoom lens; and the dimension of the device is substantially smaller than the currently used imaging systems in digital pathology. These features provide the advantages of making digital pathology affordable, accessible and easy-to-operate when compared to the leading competing digital pathology systems and other whole imaging devices using solid optical elements in this market space.

This project addresses the following technology gaps as it translates from research discovery toward commercial application. The use of composite elastomer-liquid zoom lens greatly simplifies the optical configuration and the overall size of the imaging system. This makes it possible to have the imaging device be portable and work smoothly with mobile personal devices (smartphones and tablets). To ensure that sufficient optical resolution can be reached, the thickness profiles of the vari-thickness elastomer membranes to be used in the liquid lenses will be investigated through iterative optomechanical simulation and experimental validation. This will generate new knowledge to advance the use of elastomer-liquid lenses for many high quality imaging applications. Besides the optical performance, the device also leverages the mobile devices' unparalleled capability of instant sharing for efficient transmission of whole slide pathological images. Given the prevalence of mobile devices, their increasing processing and transmission speeds, and the versatility of mobile apps, the personal whole slide imaging device with liquid lenses is expected to serve as a valuable solution of digital pathology for enhancing research and clinical outcomes.

In addition, personnel involved in this project including graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students will receive innovation, entrepreneurship, and technology translation experiences through the interactions with potential customers, the co-creation workshop and the comprehensive mentoring by engineering scientists, pathologists, and business educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project investigates a portable whole slide imaging system that allows for rapid and low-cost slide scanning by individual pathologists. The critical components of the whole slide imaging system are variable-focus elastomer liquid lenses whose diopter ranges can be changes without dislocating any optical components. In this system, two variable-focus elastomer liquid lenses are controlled using one single actuator. Their focal lengths can be tuned simultaneously to allow for rapid and dynamic change of the zooming factor. This configuration is different from previous zoom configurations where each lens needs to be controlled by one actuator. The cost and system complexity are significantly reduced, making it possible for office use or on-site pathological examinations. The elastomer membranes in the variable-focus elastomer liquid lenses have a varying thickness profile, which can significantly reduce optical aberrations and thus allow for microscopic imaging with high spatial resolution. The whole slide imaging systems can be operated with low-cost and commercially accessible portable electronic devices, such as a smartphone or a tablet.  The customers without the access to high-end whole slide imaging device can, for the first time, perform slide scanning at an affordable cost. Several other technical strategies that control variable-focus zoom lens with a single actuation unit were also proposed and experimentally validated. The devices have also attracted great attentions from clinical researchers and investors in various industrial sectors. The technologies have been licensed and the commercialization is ongoing. In addition, several doctoral students have been trained and graduated from this project. Some are now working in leading medical device and consuming electronics companies to continue their contributions on liquid lens technologies in respective fields.
